snp2.1:1.2.eng: on the ground or in the sky:

snp2.1:1.3.eng: may beings all be of happy heart,

snp2.1:1.4.eng: and listen carefully to what is said.
snp2.1:1.4.comm: The gods are invoked in the Vedic fashion. Compare eg. Rig Veda 6.52.13a: “May all gods hear my call, whether in the sky or in heaven.”

snp2.1:2.1.eng: So pay heed, all you beings,

snp2.1:2.3.pli: Divā ca ratto ca haranti ye baliṃ,
snp2.1:2.3.eng: who day and night bring offerings;

snp2.1:3.1.pli: Yaṃ kiñci vittaṃ idha vā huraṃ vā,
snp2.1:3.1.eng: There’s no wealth in this life or the next,

snp2.1:3.2.eng: no sublime gem in the heavens,

snp2.1:3.4.eng: This sublime gem is in the Buddha:

snp2.1:3.5.eng: by this truth, may you be well!
snp2.1:3.5.comm: The asseveration of truth—the belief that “by this truth” (tena saccena, also at MN 86:15.2) effective results could be won—can be traced to Rig Veda 1.21.6 (tena satyena).

snp2.1:4.1.eng: Ending, dispassion, the undying, the sublime,

snp2.1:4.2.eng: attained by the Sakyan Sage immersed in samādhi;

snp2.1:4.3.eng: there is nothing equal to that Dhamma.

snp2.1:4.4.eng: This sublime gem is in the Dhamma:

snp2.1:4.5.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:5.1.eng: The purity praised by the highest Buddha

snp2.1:5.2.eng: is said to be the “immersion with immediate fruit”;

snp2.1:5.3.eng: no equal to that immersion is found.

snp2.1:5.4.eng: This sublime gem is in the Dhamma:

snp2.1:5.5.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:6.1.eng: The eight individual persons praised by the good

snp2.1:6.2.eng: are the four pairs of the Holy One’s disciples;

snp2.1:6.3.eng: they are worthy of religious donations,

snp2.1:6.4.eng: what’s given to them is very fruitful.

snp2.1:6.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:6.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:7.3.eng: they’ve attained the goal, <j>plunged into freedom from death,

snp2.1:7.4.eng: and enjoy the quenching they’ve freely gained.

snp2.1:7.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:7.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:8.1.eng: As Indra’s pillar rooted in earth

snp2.1:8.2.eng: is not shaken by the four winds,

snp2.1:8.3.eng: I say a true person is like this,

snp2.1:8.4.eng: who sees the noble truths in experience.

snp2.1:8.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:8.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:9.1.eng: Those who fathom the noble truths

snp2.1:9.2.eng: taught by the one of deep wisdom,

snp2.1:9.3.eng: do not take an eighth life,

snp2.1:9.4.eng: even if they are hugely negligent.

snp2.1:9.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:9.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:11.1.eng: They’re freed from the four places of loss,
snp2.1:11.1.comm: Hell (niraya), the animal realm, the ghost realm (petivisaya), and the abode of the demons (asuraloka).

snp2.1:11.2.comm: This is often identified with the six heinous crimes beginning with murdering one’s mother (AN 6.94). However, there are three other lists of six things that do not mention these heinous crimes (AN 6.92, AN 6.93, AN 6.95). They include such errors as taking what is impermanent to be permanent.

snp2.1:11.3.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:11.4.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:12.1.eng: Even if they do a bad deed

snp2.1:12.3.eng: they are unable to conceal it;

snp2.1:12.4.eng: this inability applies to <j>one who has seen the truth, they say.

snp2.1:12.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:12.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:13.1.eng: Like a tall forest tree crowned with flowers

snp2.1:13.2.eng: in the first month of summer;

snp2.1:13.3.eng: that’s how he taught the superb Dhamma,

snp2.1:13.4.eng: leading to extinguishment, the ultimate benefit.

snp2.1:13.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Buddha:

snp2.1:13.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:14.1.eng: The superb, knower of the superb, <j>giver of the superb, bringer of the superb;

snp2.1:14.3.eng: This sublime gem is in the Buddha:

snp2.1:14.4.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:15.1.eng: The old is ended, nothing new is produced.

snp2.1:15.2.eng: their minds have no desire for future rebirth.

snp2.1:15.3.eng: Withered are the seeds, there’s no desire for growth,

snp2.1:15.4.eng: those attentive ones are extinguished like this lamp.

snp2.1:15.5.eng: This sublime gem is in the Saṅgha:

snp2.1:15.6.eng: by this truth, may you be well!

snp2.1:16.2.eng: on the ground or in the sky:

snp2.1:16.3.eng: the Realized One is honored by gods and humans!

snp2.1:16.4.eng: We bow to the Buddha! May you be safe!

snp2.1:17.2.eng: on the ground or in the sky:

snp2.1:17.3.eng: the Realized One is honored by gods and humans!

snp2.1:17.4.eng: We bow to the Dhamma! May you be safe!

snp2.1:18.2.eng: on the ground or in the sky:

snp2.1:18.3.eng: the Realized One is honored by gods and humans!

snp2.1:18.4.eng: We bow to the Saṅgha! May you be safe!

snp2.10:1.2.eng: What’s the point in your sleeping?

snp2.10:1.4.eng: when inflicted by an arrow strike?

snp2.10:2.3.eng: The King of Death has caught you heedless—

snp2.10:2.4.eng: don’t let him fool you under his sway.

snp2.10:3.4.eng: Don’t let the moment pass you by.

snp2.10:3.5.eng: For if you miss your moment

snp2.10:3.6.eng: you’ll grieve when sent to hell.

snp2.10:4.4.eng: pluck out the dart from yourself.

snp2.11:1.2.eng: even for the man of wisdom?

snp2.11:1.3.eng: Do you honor he who holds aloft

snp2.11:2.3.eng: I always honor he who holds aloft

snp2.11:3.1.eng: “One who’s given up the five sensual stimulations,

snp2.11:3.3.eng: and who’s left the home life out of faith—

snp2.11:3.4.eng: let them make an end to suffering!

snp2.11:5.4.eng: don’t come back to this world again.

snp2.11:6.1.eng: Be restrained in the monastic code,

snp2.11:6.3.eng: With mindfulness immersed in the body,

snp2.11:7.4.eng: meditate on the ugly aspects of the body.

snp2.11:8.2.eng: give up the tendency to conceit;

snp2.11:9.1.pli: Itthaṃ sudaṃ bhagavā āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ imāhi gāthāhi abhiṇhaṃ ovadatīti.
snp2.11:9.1.eng: That is how the Buddha regularly advised Venerable Rāhula with these verses.

snp2.12:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā āḷaviyaṃ viharati aggāḷave cetiye.
snp2.12:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī, at Āḷavī’s premier shrine.

snp2.12:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato vaṅgīsassa upajjhāyo nigrodhakappo nāma thero aggāḷave cetiye aciraparinibbuto hoti.
snp2.12:1.3.eng: Now at that time it was not long after Venerable Vaṅgīsa’s mentor, the senior monk named Nigrodhakappa, had become fully quenched.

snp2.12:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmato vaṅgīsassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
snp2.12:1.4.eng: Then as Vaṅgīsa was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:

snp2.12:1.5.pli: parinibbuto nu kho me upajjhāyo udāhu no parinibbutoti?
snp2.12:1.5.eng: “Has my mentor become quenched or not?”

snp2.12:1.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—
snp2.12:1.6.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Vaṅgīsa came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

snp2.12:1.7.pli: idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
snp2.12:1.7.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.

snp2.12:1.8.pli: parinibbuto nu kho me upajjhāyo, udāhu no parinibbutoti.
snp2.12:1.8.eng: ‘Has my mentor become quenched or not?’”

snp2.12:1.9.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
snp2.12:1.9.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and addressed him in verse:

snp2.12:2.1.eng: “I ask the teacher unrivaled in wisdom,

snp2.12:2.2.eng: who has cut off all doubts in this very life:

snp2.12:2.3.eng: a monk has died at Āḷavī’s premier shrine,

snp2.12:2.4.eng: who was well-known, famous, and quenched.

snp2.12:3.2.eng: it was given to that brahmin by you, Blessed One.

snp2.12:3.3.eng: He wandered in your honor, yearning for freedom,

snp2.12:3.4.eng: energetic, a resolute Seer of Truth.

snp2.12:4.2.eng: we all wish to know about that disciple.

snp2.12:4.3.eng: Our ears are eager to hear,

snp2.12:4.4.eng: for you are the most excellent teacher.

snp2.12:5.1.eng: Cut off our doubt, declare this to us;

snp2.12:5.2.eng: your wisdom is vast, tell us of his quenching!

snp2.12:5.4.eng: like the thousand-eyed Sakka <j>in the midst of the gods!

snp2.12:6.1.eng: Whatever ties there are, or paths to delusion,

snp2.12:6.2.eng: or things on the side of unknowing, <j>or that are bases of doubt

snp2.12:6.3.eng: vanish on reaching a Realized One,

snp2.12:6.4.eng: for his eye is the best of all people’s.

snp2.12:7.1.pli: No ce hi jātu puriso kilese,
snp2.12:7.1.eng: If no man were ever to disperse corruptions,

snp2.12:7.2.eng: like the wind dispersing the stormclouds,

snp2.12:7.3.eng: darkness would shroud the whole world;

snp2.12:7.4.eng: not even brilliant men would shine.

snp2.12:8.1.eng: The attentive are bringers of light;

snp2.12:8.2.pli: Taṃ taṃ ahaṃ vīra tatheva maññe;
snp2.12:8.2.eng: my hero, that is what I think of you.

snp2.12:8.3.eng: We’ve come for your discernment and knowledge:

snp2.12:8.4.eng: here in this assembly, declare to us about Kappāyana.

snp2.12:9.1.eng: Swiftly send forth your sweet, sweet voice,

snp2.12:9.2.eng: like a goose stretching its neck, gently honking,

snp2.12:9.4.eng: alert, we all listen to you.

snp2.12:10.1.eng: You have entirely abandoned birth and death;

snp2.12:10.2.eng: restrained and pure, I urge you to speak the Dhamma!

snp2.12:10.3.eng: For while ordinary people have no wish-granter,
snp2.12:10.3.comm: Kāmakāro: “wish-granter”. Ordinary people cannot simply get what they want.

snp2.12:10.4.comm: Saṅkheyyakāro: “comprehensibility-granter”. Saṅkheyya is “calculable, comprehensible”, not “after comprehension”. The Buddha has a gift for explaining things in a way that makes them comprehensible.

snp2.12:11.1.eng: Your answer is definitive, and we will adopt it,

snp2.12:11.3.eng: We raise our joined palms one last time,

snp2.12:11.4.eng: one of unrivaled wisdom, <j>don’t deliberately confuse us.

snp2.12:12.1.eng: Knowing the noble teaching from top to bottom,

snp2.12:12.2.eng: unrivaled hero, don’t deliberately confuse us.

snp2.12:12.3.eng: As a man baking in the summer sun <j>would long for water,

snp2.12:12.4.eng: I long for your voice, so let the sound rain  forth.

snp2.12:13.1.eng: Surely Kappāyana did not <j>lead the spiritual life in vain?

snp2.12:13.3.eng: or did he still have a residue?

snp2.12:13.4.eng: Let us hear what kind of liberation he had!”

snp2.12:14.1.eng: “He cut off craving for name and form right here,”

snp2.12:14.3.eng: “the river of darkness that had long lain within him.

snp2.12:14.4.eng: He has entirely crossed over birth and death.”

snp2.12:14.5.eng: So declared the Blessed One, the leader of the five.

snp2.12:15.1.eng: “Now that I have heard your words,

snp2.12:15.2.eng: seventh of seers, I am confident.

snp2.12:15.3.eng: My question, it seems, was not in vain,

snp2.12:15.4.eng: the brahmin did not deceive me.

snp2.12:16.1.eng: As he said, so he did—

snp2.12:16.2.eng: he was a disciple of the Buddha.

snp2.12:16.3.eng: He cut the net of death the deceiver,

snp2.12:17.3.eng: He has indeed gone far beyond

snp2.12:17.4.eng: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.”

snp2.13:1.1.eng: “I ask the sage abounding in wisdom—

snp2.13:1.3.eng: when a mendicant has left home, casting aside sensuality,

snp2.13:1.4.pli: Kathaṃ bhikkhu sammā so loke paribbajeyya”.
snp2.13:1.4.eng: what’s the right way to wander the world?”

snp2.13:2.3.eng: “about celestial portents, dreams, or bodily marks;

snp2.13:2.4.eng: with the stain of superstitions left behind,

snp2.13:3.3.eng: with rebirth transcended and truth comprehended,

snp2.13:4.2.eng: a mendicant gives up anger and stinginess;

snp2.13:4.3.eng: with favoring and opposing left behind,

snp2.13:5.1.eng: When the loved and the unloved are both left behind,

snp2.13:5.2.eng: not grasping or dependent on anything;

snp2.13:5.3.eng: freed from all things that fetter,

snp2.13:6.2.eng: rid of desire for things they’ve acquired,

snp2.13:6.3.eng: independent, needing no-one to guide them,

snp2.13:7.1.eng: Not hostile in speech, mind, or deed,

snp2.13:7.3.eng: Aspiring to the state of extinguishment,

snp2.13:8.1.eng: Not gloating that, ‘they bow to me’;

snp2.13:8.2.eng: though reviled, they’d still stay in touch;
snp2.13:8.2.comm: Neither Norman nor Bodhi note sandhiyatimeva in identical context at AN 3.132:3.2. There Bodhi has “remains on friendly terms”, I have “stay in touch”. I assume there is a confusion of the negative which is required to give the correct sense. If I’m right, the corruption must predate the commentary.

snp2.13:8.3.eng: not besotted when getting food from others,

snp2.13:9.1.eng: When greed and craving to live again are cast off,

snp2.13:9.2.eng: a mendicant refrains from violence and abduction;

snp2.13:9.3.eng: rid of indecision, free of thorns,

snp2.13:10.1.eng: Knowing what is suitable for themselves,

snp2.13:10.2.pli: No ca bhikkhu hiṃseyya kañci loke;
snp2.13:10.2.eng: a mendicant would hurt no-one in the world;

snp2.13:10.3.eng: understanding the teaching in line with the truth,

snp2.13:11.1.eng: They have no underlying tendencies at all,

snp2.13:11.2.eng: and are rid of unskillful roots;

snp2.13:11.3.eng: free of hope, with no need for hope,

snp2.13:13.1.eng: Faithful, learned, seer of the sure path,

snp2.13:13.2.eng: an attentive one joins no faction among sects;

snp2.13:13.3.eng: rid of greed, hate, and repulsion,

snp2.13:14.1.eng: A purified victor with veil cast off,

snp2.13:14.2.eng: among worldly things master, transcendent, stilled;

snp2.13:14.3.eng: expert in knowledge of conditions’ cessation,

snp2.13:15.1.eng: They’re over speculating on the future or past,

snp2.13:15.2.eng: and understand what it means to be pure;

snp2.13:15.3.eng: freed from all the sense fields,

snp2.13:16.1.eng: The state of peace is understood, <j>the truth is comprehended,

snp2.13:16.2.eng: they’ve openly seen defilements cast off;

snp2.13:16.3.eng: and with the ending of all attachments,

snp2.13:17.1.eng: “Clearly, Blessed One, it is just as you say.

snp2.13:17.2.eng: One who lives like this is a tamed mendicant,

snp2.13:17.3.eng: passed beyond all fetters and yokes:
